ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
-Ability to interpret spectra of various metal centers from literature
- Knowledge of theory pertaining to various spectroscopic techniques, including optical spectroscopy, EPR, Raman, IR, ESEEM, ENDOR, CD, MCD, Mossbauer, XANES, EXASFS, and molecular magentism. Of these techniques, I was most comfortable with optical spectroscopy, EPR, and XANES and EXASFS because of the literature presentation topic I chose.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Clearest strength of this course was the instructor's enthusiasm and willingness to help the student. I scheduled office hours several times outside of class to try to clarify material concepts and the professor was always willing to accommodate. I think another strength of this course was the frequent homeworks and the fact that they were graded on effort. This encouraged me to keep up with the material and do consistent review of the concepts covered in lecture, and made me feel less discouraged from getting questions incorrect on the homework (which I personally thought were challenging). I also liked that the instructor released an answer key for the homeworks. Lastly, the final exam I thought was quite fair.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For any inorganic track student or biophysical chemistry student who needs to engage with any type of spectroscopy related to metal complexes, this is an essential course. By the end of the half semester, my ability to understand the literature of the field which utilized some of the spectroscopic techniques was significantly better than the beginning. This course was fairly challenging for me, and it was definitely out of my comfort zone but I'm glad I took it with the instructor that taught it.
